articles.headline: President Raises Stakes in Supreme Court Nominee Battle
articles.snippet: During a news conference, President Obama said there was no basis in the Constitution for Republicans to refuse to hold hearings and vote on his nominee.
articles.abstract: During a news conference, President Obama said there was no basis in the Constitution for Republicans to refuse to hold hearings and vote on his nominee.
articles.lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama on Tuesday challenged Republicans to offer a plausible rationale for refusing to consider a Supreme Court candidate to replace Justice Antonin Scalia, and he pledged to nominate someone with an “outstanding legal mind” who cares about democracy and the rule of law.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: Young Saudis See Cushy Jobs Vanish Along With Nation’s Oil Wealth
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia has survived oil shocks before, but now 70 percent of its citizens are under 30, and they face a harder future than their parents.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia has survived oil shocks before, but now 70 percent of its citizens are under 30, and they face a harder future than their parents.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — In pressed white robes and clutching crisp résumés, young Saudi men packed a massive hall at a university in the capital city this month to wait in long lines to pitch themselves to employers.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Candidacy Reveals Generational Schism Among Women
articles.snippet: Many younger women identify strongly with their generation’s collective concerns, in contrast with older women who have focused on a woman reaching the presidency.
articles.abstract: Many younger women identify strongly with their generation’s collective concerns, in contrast with older women who have focused on a woman reaching the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — In the sun-drenched student center on the Pennsylvania State University campus here, a few days after Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont trounced Hillary Clinton in the New Hampshire Democratic primary last week, Renee Tillman, Melanie Suarez and Kamryn Sandidge were picking at their lunchtime salads when they were asked if they considered themselves feminists.

articles.headline: Virtual Reality Companies Look to Science Fiction for Their Next Play
articles.snippet: Science fiction is both shaping the language that virtual reality companies use to market the technology and defining long-term goals for developers.
articles.abstract: Science fiction is both shaping the language that virtual reality companies use to market the technology and defining long-term goals for developers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tech companies have spent years developing better, cheaper devices to immerse people in digital worlds. Yet they are still figuring out how to make virtual reality the kind of technology that people cannot live without.

articles.headline: Obama’s Options for a Supreme Court Nominee, and the Potential Fallout
articles.snippet: Both parties are calculating how to leverage the vacancy on the court. There are many possible paths, with political consequences on both sides.
articles.abstract: Both parties are calculating how to leverage the vacancy on the court. There are many possible paths, with political consequences on both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia immediately prompted lofty-sounding pronouncements from leaders of both parties. But behind the public statements, the two parties are engaged in raw political calculations about how to best leverage the vacancy, underscoring the country’s deep polarization and the reality of how elections are waged nowadays.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Muslims in France Say Emergency Powers Go Too Far
articles.snippet: Critics of the state of emergency say the human cost of warrantless searches has been disproportionate to their efficacy.
articles.abstract: Critics of the state of emergency say the human cost of warrantless searches has been disproportionate to their efficacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Depending on who is telling the story, Daoud Muradyan, a blind 21-year-old, is either a potential terrorist or a harmless immigrant who embodies everything that is wrong with France’s broad new antiterrorism powers.

articles.headline: Apple Fights Order to Unlock San Bernardino Gunman’s iPhone
articles.snippet: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief, said the government’s request to bypass security on the phone used by Syed Rizwan Farook had “chilling” implications.
articles.abstract: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief, said the government’s request to bypass security on the phone used by Syed Rizwan Farook had “chilling” implications.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last month, some of President Obama’s top intelligence advisers met in Silicon Valley with Apple’s chief, Timothy D. Cook, and other technology leaders in what seemed to be a public rapprochement in their long-running dispute over the encryption safeguards built into their devices.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Katie Benner
